citations.narrative:
One cougar does not have access to an appropriate climatic shelter to prevent discomfort. When the inspector walked up
to the enclosure, the cougar was sheltering in a commercial plastic dog crate. After exiting the crate to greet people, she
repeatedly picked up her paws and shook them as she walked around the enclosure. She had frozen, wet fur on the
outside back left leg and left side of the tail. Inside the crate was a small amount of wet straw bedding. No wind breaks
were provided either by covering the crate’s ventilation holes or placing any wind barriers in or around the enclosure. The
inspector’s phone weather app displaced a temperature of -3 degrees Fahrenheit for the current location.
Inadequate shelters do not afford animals protection from wind, rain, snow or other weather extremes. Cold weather
exposure can lead to hypothermia and/or unnecessary stress and discomfort. The licensee must ensure that all animals
have access to appropriate shelter for the local climatic conditions and that shelters provide adequate protection to
prevent discomfort. The licensee added bedding at the time of inspection.
Correct by December 12, 2025 (end of business day).
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.127(b)  Direct
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
One cougar does not have access to an appropriate climatic shelter to prevent discomfort. When the inspector walked up 
to the enclosure, the cougar was sheltering in a commercial plastic dog crate. After exiting the crate to greet people, she 
repeatedly picked up her paws and shook them as she walked around the enclosure. She had frozen, wet fur on the 
outside back left leg and left side of the tail. Inside the crate was a small amount of wet straw bedding. No wind breaks 
were provided either by covering the crate’s ventilation holes or placing any wind barriers in or around the enclosure. The 
inspector’s phone weather app displaced a temperature of -3 degrees Fahrenheit for the current location.  
 
Inadequate shelters do not afford animals protection from wind, rain, snow or other weather extremes. Cold weather 
exposure can lead to hypothermia and/or unnecessary stress and discomfort. The licensee must ensure that all animals 
have access to appropriate shelter for the local climatic conditions and that shelters provide adequate protection to 
prevent discomfort. The licensee added bedding at the time of inspection. 
 
Correct by December 12, 2025 (end of business day). 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
